Unfortunately, the disbursement for this loan was marked late.  However, Menyikwa Enterprises SHG has repaid $616!  It is now 13% complete in its repayment.

Thank you for your support of this group.

Sincerely,
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Casilda

texts.es:
Casilda is a very diligent person with a desire to get ahead. She started her agricultural activities as a child and recently decided to raise sheep and in little time she improved her stock and her business has been growing by the day. She sells her animals and also shears them after several months. Her main concern is supporting her dear children and this is the reason she wants to increase her investment capital to buy more sheep.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Casilda es una persona muy diligente y con deseos D. superación. Dio comienzo a sus actividades agrícolas desD. niña, y recientemente decidió criar ovejas y en poco tiempo mejoró sus razas, su actividad se ha estado capitalizando y aumentando cada día más, ella venD. sus animales pero a la vez después D. varios meses los trasquila, su mayor preocupación es apoyar a sus amados hijos y por esa razón quiere incrementar su capital D. inversión para comprar más ovejas.

loans.use: Injection of capital to muy more sheep

loans.name: Ulises

texts.es:
The farming business requires great sacrifice and dedication, and thus an efficient management of the crops and even moreso the well treatment of the application of fertilizers that protect the crops for harvest is essential.

At the moment, it is important to emphasize that Ulises makes every effort to sustain his household. He seeks a loan from Ceprodel to obtain credit that will allow him to invest in his crops. With this loan, he and his family will benefit immensely. He anxiously hopes that his business will prosper so that he can improve his way of life.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

El negocio agropecuario es una labor que requiere de muchísimo esfuerzo y dedicación debido a que se debe de tener un eficiente control en el cultivo y además se debe contar con buenos tratamientos de aplicación por medio de productos como fertilizantes que protejan el cultivo hasta recoger la cosecha.

Actualmente es necesario destacar que el caballero Ulises para llevar el sustento a su hogar de habitación brinda todos sus esfuerzos al negocio. Hoy en día muy sabiamente busca apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener un crédito que le permita invertir en el cultivo, con este apoyo se beneficia tanto él y su familia el cual muy ansiosamente espera que el negocio prospere para mejorar su nivel de vida.

loans.use: To improve his crops

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes is a very hard working person and she is demanding of herself in every job that she starts. For years at her husband's siD. she has been working support her 4 children who are now grown men and women. Now that she is only living with her dear husband she works in the areas that are within her reach; she raises guinea pigs which are a great help in supporting themselves and despite the frigid climate in her area she keeps them well fed and in safe keeping so that she can realize the fruits of her labor. She has her own alfalfa crop field to proviD. the daily feed for her little animals. She would like to improve her farm and buy the necessary things for the construction of a barn in order to augment her sales and breeding business.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Mercedes es una persona muy trabajadora y se auto exige en cada trabajo que emprenD., durante años al lado D. su esposo han estado trabajando para mantener a sus 4 hijos que ahora son hombres y mujeres D. bien, ahora sola en compañía D. su amado esposo trabaja en las tareas que están a su alcance; ellos crían cuyes los cuales son D. vital ayuda para sostenerse y a pesar del clima frígido D. su zona los mantiene muy bien y a buen recaudo para observar los frutos D. su trabajo. Cuenta con su propio campo D. cultivo D. alfalfa para disponer del alimento diario D. sus animalitos. Desea mejorar su granja y comprar lo necesario para la construcción D. sus galpones a fin D. una mejor distribución y crianza.

loans.use: Construction of a barn for her animals

loans.name: Carmen Odily

texts.es:
In the municipality of Condega in Estelí de Nicaragua, Ms Carmen Odily C. makes a great sacrifice to provide the necessary living conditions for her family. For this reason she has decided to improve her home. Upon starting the remodeling and having only put up a single wall, she recognized her lack of economic resources. Today, in order to continue with her project she has decided to ask for a loan from Ceprodel which will allow her to purchase construction materials for her home.

Ms Carmen will benefit enormously through your support because she will be able to provide her family with better living conditions which will in turn help her family's development and give them a worthy roof over their heads.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

En el municipio de Condega en Estelí de Nicaragua, la señora Carmen Odily C. se esfuerza grandemente con el propósito de brindar a su familia (su hija) las condiciones necesarias para vivir. Por ello al ver la necesidad de mejora de su vivienda ha decidido reconstruir su casa de habitación y al haber comenzado con esta labor se vió en la necesidad de detenerse por la falta de recurso económico habiendo solamente levantado una pared en su vivienda. Hoy en día para continuar con esta labor ha decidido solicitar crédito en Ceprodel para obtener el recurso económico que le permita la compra de los materiales de construcción para su vivienda.

Por medio de este apoyo es de suma importancia destacar que la señora Carmen será grandemente beneficiada porque así logrará brindar a su familia las condiciones necesarias para su desarrollo y para tener un techo digno donde habitar.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for her home

loans.name: Gumercinda

texts.es:
Gumercinda is a woman with a noble heart. She is a humble farmer who dedicates herself daily to the care of her fields, with the purpose of caring for her elderly mother and her young daughter. Her fields have responded well to her care, but are in need of natural fertilizers.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

Gumercinda es una mujer de un corazón muy noble y solidario, ella es una humilde agricultora que se dedica diariamente a cuidar de sus campos de cultivo con el propósito de otorgarle bienestar a su anciana madre y el de su pequeña niña.Sus campos han respondido muy bien a sus cuidados, sin embargo aún necesitan de abonos y fertilizantes naturales.

loans.use: Purchase of natural fertilizers

loans.name: Wiler

texts.es:
Leadership and interest in the progress of his land make Mr. Wiler a standout farmer in his community. He is always worried about his self-development and participates actively to improve himself, and his work of farming better potatoes, barley, onions, and herbs. His dedication is motivated by his love for his children, and he hopes that by improving his fields, he may be able to increase his income. Support this dedicated father with a loan for the purchase of fertilizers and the education of his children.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

El liderazgo y el interés por el progreso de su tierra hacen de Don Wiler un agricultor destacado en su comunidad, siempre está preocupado por los temas que vinculan su desarrollo y participa activamente para su mejoramiento, él trabaja cultivando papa, cebada, cebolla y pastos mejorados, su dedicación está motivada por el amor de sus hijos y espera mejorar sus cultivos a fin de que pueda obtener mayores ganancias. Apoya a este padre de familia dedicado a su familia que solicita un préstamo para invertirlos en la compra de fertilizantes y en la educación de sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer.

loans.name: Eladia

texts.es:
Eladia is a young mother of an enthusiastic family. She is a very hard worker, who rises early in the morning to harvest herbs from her fields, feed the cow, and farm potatoes. She wants to increase the set up of her business to improve production and earnings. She works for the well-being and happiness of her 2 small children. In order satisfy her goal for a higher quality of life, she needs to improve upon potato planting and also improve cow feeding, for which she seeks this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

Eladia, es una joven madre de familia entusiasta y muy trabajadora se levanta muy temprano por las mañanas para recoger el pA. de sus campos y así poder alimentar a su vaca, también se dedica al cultivo de papa y quiere acrecentar las instalaciones de su establo para tener mayor producción y ganancias, trabaja porque quiere ver a sus 2 pequeños hijos bien y muy contentos, para alcanzar su objetivo con satisfacción necesita mejorar su siembra de papas y también alimentar mejor a su vaca para lo cual solicita un préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase of natural fertilizers and feed

loans.name: Menyikwa Jua Kali Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Hyline K. is an average Kenyan woman. She's 29 years old and has three children. She also lives with the orphaned child of her late brother.

Hyline started operating her business two years ago after accumulating savings from her former work place in a local school in Kisii town. She currently operates a small retail vegetable business, selling kale, tomatoes, onions, cabbages, bananas, and mangos to customers in the neighborhood.

Hyline must support her children and her husband, who has a low-paying job. With the help of her loan, she'll be able to purchase more stock of different vegetables and fruits, which will enable her to increase sales. This will also enable her to pay school fees for her children.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To increase stock of vegetables and fruits

payments.comment:
Dear Lender,

Unfortunately, the disbursement on this loan was marked late.  However, Menyikwa Jua Kali SHG has repaid $921 of its loan!  It is now 44% complete in repaying to Kiva lenders.

Sincerely,
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Yeni

texts.es:
Yeni is a hard working person and she puts all of her efforts into caring for her two children, who are becoming her reason for living. One of the services which she offers to the community is working as an entry level professor, but at the same time, she farms beans, potatoes, and onions for sustenance. She works very hard daily, teaching and caring for her fields. Her hope is to improve her harvest in the next planting season, for which she is already preparing one of her feilds, and asking for a loan for the purchase of fertilizer.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

Yeni, es una persona muy trabajadora y se esfuerza siempre por mantener a sus 2 hijos que se han convertido en su razón de vida. Ella ofrece sus servicios a la comunidad como profesora de nivel inicial pero a su vez se dedica al cultivo de habas, papa y cebolla que le sirven de sustento. A diario trabaja intensamente enseñando y cuidando sus campos de cultivo, su deseo es mejorar su cosecha en las próximas épocas de siembra y para este fin está preparando una de sus tierras de cultivo y solicita un préstamo de para la compra de abono.

loans.use: Purchase of natural fertilizers.

loans.name: Karina

texts.es:
Heritage and tradition have turned into a good option for making a living for Karina, a good mother of a family that lives to care for her 8 year-old son. She is an expert in the kitchen, and with her mother, she offers to their distinguished clientele the most exquisite plates in the region in a restaurant inside of her own house. Apart from this, she offers her cooking classes/ kitchen services to large groups according to their requests. Karina's wish is to become more well-known and to increase this business which has brought her great satisfaction.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

La herencia y tradición se ha convertido en una buena opción de vida para Karina, una noble madre de familia que vive para brindarle toda la comodidad a su pequeño hijo de 8 años, ella es experta en la cocina y en sociedad con su mamá ofrece a su más distinguida clientela los platos más exquisitos de su región en un restaurante que instaló en su misma casa, además adicionalmente ofrecen sus servicios de cocina a grandes grupos de acuerdo a los pedidos, el anhelo de Karina es hacerse más conocida y acrecentar este negocio que le ha traído muchas satisfacciones.

loans.use: Contracting public services and covering the costs of the store

loans.name: Evelyne

texts.es:
Evelyne is dedicated to improving her quality of life, and does not scrimp on any efforts to achieve this, as her responsibility as a mother is her major driving force. She has been working for two years raising animals such as chickens, rabbits, and guinea pigs, but she also raises cows to sell at the fairs in Jauja. She built a small stable in her house in order to do this, and her earnings recompense her long term efforts to care for these animals. She is very enthusiastic about continuing to raise animals, since this will be the thing which will permit her to improve conditions. She ask for a loan to purchase a cow and a shed for her guinea pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

Evelyne, esta decidida a mejorar su calidad de vida y no escatima esfuerzos por lograrlo ya que su responsabilidad de madre es su más grande impulso. Hace 2 años decidió criar animales menores como: pollos conejos y cuyes pero también cría vacas para luego venderlas en la ferias de Jauja, implementó en su casa un pequeño establo para poder hacerlo y las ganancias retribuyen su esfuerzo después de todo un período de cuidados es por esa razón que está muy animada a continuar con la crianza de animales ya que esto le permitirá estar en mejores condiciones. Solicita un préstamo para invertirlos en la compra de una vaca y galpones para sus cuyes.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow and a shed for her guinea pigs

loans.name: Obomo Getembe Kiagasuku Group

texts.en:
Serpine B. is a young Kenyan mother. She is 28 years old with three children. She also lives with the orphaned child of her late sister, who perished two years ago.

Serpine started her business three years ago after accumulating savings from her former workplace. She currently sells ladies' shoes but would like to diversify her inventory by adding children's and men’s collections. As the breadwinner of her family, this would enable her to support both her children and her husband, who does not have a job.

With the little profit that she gets from the business, Serpine still struggles to pay the house rent and feed, clothe, and educate her children. With the help of her loan, she will be able to add more stock and increase her monthly sales.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes in bulk to sell

loans.name: Happy

texts.en: Happy is thirty-six years old and a divorced mother with five children. All her children are in school. She has been selling used ladies' bags, belts and purses for the past ten years. Happy buys her wares from Accra to retail in her town. She wants to use her loan to buy more bags and purses to increase sales and income so as to increase her savings to enable her take care of the children’s education. She is a member of the group called Royal Priesthood. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more used ladies' bags and purses.

loans.name: Theodore

texts.en: Theodore is a married man and the father of two children. Currently the children are in school. He has been able to open a small grocery shop for his wife to enable her also to receive income to support the family. Theodore wants to use his new loan to buy brand new and used car batteries and electrical wires to expand his own business. This will enable him to increase sales and income to support his family. He is a member of the group called Beloved. Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more electrical wires and car batteries

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana wants to use her loan to buy more materials like polyester and linen to avoid price hikes in her products. She has been selling materials used in making dresses for schoolchildren. She is forty-eight years old and a mother of five children. Two of the children are in school. With this loan, she plans to increase savings to enable her continue to pay for the children’s education. Christiana is a member of the group called Beloved. Members of the group agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more sewing materials like polyester, linen, cloth, etc.

loans.name: Ushindi Youth Group

texts.en:
Esther W. is an average Kenyan woman. She is 38 years old and married with two children. She also lives with the two orphaned children of her late sister.

Esther started her second-hand clothing business four years ago after retiring from her teaching profession, which she had been in for over ten years. She now sells ladies' and children’s wear. She purchases bails of clothing each week from Kisii market, which is well-known for its wholesale clothes business. With the little profit that she gets from her business, Esther is still able to clothe, feed, and educate her children and relatives with the help of her husband, who works as a technician in the town of Kisii.

With the help of this loan, Esther would like to diversify her business by bringing in more men’s wear to increase her monthly sales. Her long-term vision is to expand her business into a boutique.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase more bails of used clothing to sell

payments.comment:
Dear Lender,

Unfortunately, the disbursement on this loan was marked late.  However, Ushindi Youth Group has repaid $118 of its loan!  It is now 14% complete in repaying to Kiva lenders.

Sincerely,
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina is forty-two years old and the mother of six children. Three of her children are in school. She prepares and sells local dishes like banku (a meal prepared from milled maize, eaten with palm nuts or peanut soup) and fufu (boiled cassava and plantain or cocoyam pounded together, and it is eaten with all kinds of local soups). These traditional foods are very popular for most Ghanaians and therefore the demand for such meals is high. Fautina wants to use her loan to buy more bags of cassavas, plantains, cocoyams, meat, and vegetables to expand her operation. She is a member of the called “Eye Nyame” (meaning It Is God). Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan. Her photo was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To more bags of maize, cassavas, plantains, cocoyams and vegetables.

loans.name: Yao

texts.en: Yao is married and the father of four children. Two of his children are in school. He has been selling and fixing electrical wires, repairing radios and cassette players and other electronic gadgets in his town for some years now. He wants a loan to buy more lead and cooper cables and wires to enable him expand his operations and also to increase his income to support his wife and take care of their children’s education. He plans to start saving with this new loan. Yao is a member of the group called “Eye Nyame” (meaning It Is God). Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. Yao’s photo was taken during the group’s meeting.

loans.use: To buy electrical cables and wires

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 46280

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is forty-nine years old and the mother of three children. She has been selling clothing, batik shirts, linens and other sewing materials, deodorants, perfumes and other cosmetics in Koforidua for eighteen years now. She wants to use her loan to buy more cosmetics and clothing to expand her business. Comfort is a member of the group called Good Family. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more clothing, cosmetics, deodorants, perfumes, etc

loans.name: Victory Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Miriam M. is a middle-aged Kenyan widow and a mother to two children. She also lives with two orphaned children, whom she must feed, clothe, and educate.

Miriam’s primary business is fish vending, which started four years ago. She got her initial capital from an informal rotating savings fund (commonly referred to as "merry go round") that her group had. She mainly concentrates on selling tilapia, but occasionally sells omena (small fish), which she says boosts her profit margin. Miriam mostly sells her fish on a retail basis to her regular customers. With her loan, however, she will be able to buy more tilapia to increase her sales and eventually expand to wholesale.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Expansion of fish business

payments.comment:
Dear Lender,

Unfortunately, the disbursement on this loan was marked late.  However, Victory SHG has repaid $216 of its loan!  It is now 7% complete in repaying to Kiva lenders.

Sincerely,
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en: Gifty is twenty-four years old and has been selling in bulk assorted biscuits, candies, peanuts, canned soft drinks, etc., for the past one-and-a-half years. She wants to use her loan to buy more boxes of biscuits, candies, soft drinks, peanuts, etc., to meet the demand in the market. She is a member of the group called Solace. Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of candies, biscuits, peanuts, etc.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa S. (35) is an outstanding entrepreneur who sells beauty products such as perfumes and make-up for ladies. She has a motorcycle she uses to go house by house selling a large variety of beauty products.

Teresa lives in San Estanislao and has a wide number of customers there and in the neighboring towns. In order to increase the number of towns she visits, Teresa will use the loan to buy more products and merchandise to sell, and also in addition she intends to buy a car with her earnings and savings.

A car would benefit her business in many ways. Firstly, she would be able to transport more products. Secondly, as mentioned earlier, she would be able to visit more customers and cover a wider number of towns. As a result, not only her sales would increase but also her earnings.

Teresa is very popular among girls in her town. Most of them want to buy her products because they make them feel more beautiful.

loans.use: The purchase of products for re-sale like perfume, creams, make-up,  etc.

loans.name: Yarisa

texts.en:
Yarisa is a 32-year-old woman who lives with her husband and four children in a rural community called Sabana Perdida (or the lost sheet), on the outskirts of the capital of Santo Domingo.

A while ago, Yarisa noticed that in her community there was a great need to teach children simple technical skills, so that they could be prepared to actively participate in today’s society. In response to that need, she opened a small internet center, where people could come to use the internet, and where they could also come to learn more about computers. She has worked hard to develop this business which has undoubtedly been successful. She is asking for this loan so that she can buy a small car. With the car she intends to provide transportation services for people interested in taking her computer classes, but who are otherwise unable to travel to her location, or who can not send their children alone to her business. For this summer she has already planned and sold out places for a computer summer camp; she has worked hard to advertise for this camp, and says that she actually has a waiting list of children whose parents are paying to send them. Without this loan though, she would not be able to provide the necessary transportation to her clients so that they could attend her camp.

Her dream is to make her business bigger and better; one day in the next two years, she wants to offer computer courses, as well as reading and writing courses (because many people in her community are illiterate). One of her own children has special needs, and so she says one of her most important dreams is to provide a good future for her daughter—to always give her the support and love that her disability requires. For herself, it is her goal to always work towards improving her life, and who she is as a person.

On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Yarisa herself, we thank you for your support with this micro loan! Yarisa’s vision and motivation are truly exceptional and it will be an honor for all of us to watch her make good.

loans.use: To invest in her internet and technology center, and to develop a summer training camp for children

loans.name: Victorio

texts.en:
Today Victorio C. Romero (42) is running two different businesses. The first one he started five years ago. He opened a grocery store in his own house, where he sells a wide range of products from food and drinks to cleaning products. The second business includes agriculture and cattle.

Victorio has land where he cultivates crops such as corn, sesame, and tobacco. In addition, he has cattle. As can be seen, Victorio knows how to take advantage of various business opportunities. He is always looking for a good way to make profits. This loan is destined for the purchase of land in order to increase the number of crops.

Victorio lives in Chore and is married to Juana Garcia (40). The couple has 6 children who are attending primary and secondary school.

loans.use: to purchase land

loans.name: Eleno

texts.es:
Mr. Eleno C., is 65 years old and is married to Mrs. Pastora who is 67 years old. They have their own home which they share with their son who works with them selling crafts.

Mr. Eleno has been a craftsman since birth as his parents and grandparents also devoted themselves to making crafts, specifically to making shawls, hammocks and cotton blankets. Today Eleno makes some of his products and purchases others from other craftspeople since the demand for the product is great and the production is time consuming.

Initially, Eleno only sold his goods in the city of Coronel Ovideo but the competition in the market forced him to expand his sales to the north of the country where he now goes with his son to sell his products. Eleno also manages an organization of craftspeople in order to obtain opportunities for them such as credit and market support for their products.

The loan which Eleno requests will be used to purchase threads, coverlets, hammocks and blankets among other goods. His discipline and perseverance provide an example for young people. He has faith that the economic and social situation in Paraguay will improve which is why he supports young craftspeople in undertaking new business opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Eleno C., tiene 65 años, esta casado, con Doña Pastora de 67 años de edad, tienen casa propia, que comparten con un hijo soltero que también trabaja en sociedad con él en la venta de artesanías.

Don Eleno es un artesano de cuna pues sus padres y abuelos también se dedicaron igual que él a la elaboración de artesanías, especialmente la confección de mantas, hamacas y colchas de hilo de algodón. Eleno hoy día confecciona algunos de sus productos y otros los compra hechos de otras artesanas, ya que la demanda del producto es muy alta y su tiempo de elaboración lleva días.

En sus primeros años sólo vendía en la ciudad de Coronel Oviedo, pero la competencia del mercado hizo que ampliara su red de acción hacia el norte del país, a donde va con su hijo a realizar las ventas. Eleno además de eso realiza gestiones como dirigente de los artesanos organizados para obtener oportunidades de apoyo crediticio y mercado para sus productos.

El dinero solicitado será destinado a la compra de: hilos, sobrecamas, hamacas, colchas, entre otros para la venta. El es un ejemplo para los jóvenes por su disciplina y constancia, él tiene fe de que la situación económica y social en el Paraguay mejorarán, esa es la razón por la que apoya a los jóvenes artesanos a emprender nuevas oportunidades de negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of cotton thread in various colors, hammocks, blankets, shawls, etc.

loans.name: Castorina's Group

texts.es:
This group was formed thanks to Castorina A. Estigarribia de Irala who is a craftsperson and a Nanduti teacher. Nanduti is a native Paraguayan lace making technique. In the guarani language it means spider web and it is embroidered on fabric in different patterns.

Castorina found out about “Fundacion Paraguaya” through a friend who told her about the group of entrepreneurial women which Fundacion sponsors for microentrepreneurial women who need help developing their businesses.

Castorina gathered a group of neighborhood women and friends to form her group after meeting for an informational meeting with one of the loan officers. The group was formed and they now work and obtain loans as a group.

The women that make up this group have different businesses such as the sale of groceries, cakes, sweet dough, crafts, kitchen supplies and the sale of clothing. This group is made up of 16 women who besides working to generate the majority of their family income are also dedicated mothers and wives.

These women also work and have businesses with the end goal of improving their neighborhood of Valle Apua de Lambare.

The loan that these women request will be invested in the purchase of ingredients used to make their food such as: meats, eggs, oil, flour, salt, vegetables, dough for empanadas, tapioca, bread, chickens, pastas, rice, etc. The women who sell clothes would like to purchase: jeans, shorts, pants, shirts, t-shirts, sports shoes and lingerie.

The women who sell cakes and sweet dough would purchase ingredients such as sugar, flour, lard, eggs, milk, “dulce de leche”, coconut, honey, etc.; and the craftspeople who make Nanduti would invest their loan in the purchase of thread in different colors, frames, fabrics and the maintenance of their sewing machines.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

Este Comité se formo gracias a la señora Castorina A. Estigarribia de Irala, quien es artesana y profesora de Ñandutí. El ñandutí es un tejido típico del Paraguay que en guaraní significa tela de araña y se borda con agujas sobre las telas y posee diferentes motivos.

Castorina conoció la Fundación Paraguaya através de una amiga quien le comento del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que desarrolla la Fundación para mujeres microempresarias que necesitan de un apoyo para desarrollar sus actividades.

Castorina juntó un grupo de mujeres vecinas y amigas del barrio para formar su grupo y luego de una reunión informativa que realizaron con unos de los oficiales de crédito se formo el grupo que hoy día trabajan y retiran sus créditos de forma solidaria.

Las mujeres que comprenden este grupo poseen distintos tipos de actividades como venta de comestibles, tortas y masas dulces, artesanías, despensas, comedores y venta de ropas. Está formado por 16 mujeres en total que además de trabajar para generar un mayor ingreso a sus familias también son madres y esposas dedicadas.

Estas mujeres también trabajan y realizan actividades con el fin de realizar mejoras en su barrio llamado Valle Apuá de Lambaré.

El crédito que solicitan desean invertirlo en la compra de ingredientes para elaborar sus comidas como: carnes, huevos, aceite, harina, sal, verduras, discos para empandas, mandioca, pan, pollos, fideos, arroz, etc. Las que se dedican a la venta de Ropas desean adquirir: jeans, bermudas, pantalones, camisas, remeras, calzados deportivos, lencerías, entre otros.

Las señoras que se dedican a la venta de tortas y masas dulces adquirirán ingredientes como harina, azúcar, manteca, huevos, leche, dulce de leche, coco, miel negra etc; y las artesanas del Ñandutí invertir su crédito en la compra de hilos de distintos colores, bastidores, telas, además en el mantenimiento de sus máquinas de coser.

loans.use: Purchase of meats, eggs, oil, flour, salt, vegetables, tapioca, bread, chickens, pastas, rices, sugar, lar, milk, sweets, honey, cheese, thread, frames, etc.

loans.name: Estrellas De Atipiri Group

texts.es:
“Estrellas de Atipiri” means Victorious Stars, a title that an association adopts after working in partnership with the Pro-Mujer family for more than two years. In addition to selling books and cosmetics, as its main activity, this association is engaged in the making and selling of shoes, which they sell on the outskirts of the city of El Alto.

A few weeks ago, the association received an order to supply school shoes. Fulfillment of this order would double their profits and improve their business and their lives. Therefore, they need additional funds to purchase raw materials for the fulfillment of this order.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Estrellas de Atipiri significa estrellas vencedoras, denominación que adopta una asociación que trabaja junto a la familia de Pro-Mujer por más dos años, además de la venta de libros y venta de cosméticos, tienen como actividad principal la confección y venta de zapatos, productos que los ofrecen en la ceja de la ciudad de El Alto. Hace unas semanas recibieron propuestas de pedidos para confeccionar zapatos para colegios, los que duplicaría sus ganancias, por lo tanto necesitan mayores créditos para la compra de insumos y materia prima, así poder realizar estos grandes pedidos, de esta manera mejorar sus negocios y su forma de vida.

loans.use: Funds to purchase raw materials

loans.name: Progreso Group

texts.es:
The group “Progreso” was formed 8 months ago and is in its third cycle of loans. The group has retained the majority of its initial members.

The women of this group have diverse productive businesses and they will use this loan as operating capital to increase what they are already achieving by purchasing more merchandise or ingredients to make their products as is the case for the women who sell food.

Among the businesses that these women dedicate themselves to are: the sale of food, fruits, vegetables, home goods, charcoal and hairdressing. Some are also dressmakers and others sell clothing.

Each one of these women hopes to give their children an education and to be able to give them good food and a good home environment. In addition to carrying out their role as mothers and wives they are also hard working and successful microentrepreneurs. They know that the current labor market becomes more competitive every day which is why they struggle so that their children will have the opportunity obtain a higher education.

They are asking for a new loan to invest in their business and keep progressing. Among the merchandise that they will purchase are: fruits such as oranges, bananas, pineapples, cantaloupes, watermelons and apples; tomatoes; lettuce; onions; carrots; charcoal; ingredients to prepare meals such as meat, milk, salt, flour; home goods and other hairdressing supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

El comité “Progreso” tiene 8 meses y ya van por su 3er ciclo de créditos como comité. El grupo mantiene a la mayoría de las primeras integrantes aun trabajando de forma solidaria.

Las de este comité se dedican a diversas actividades productivas y utilizan el préstamo como capital operativo buscando fomentar lo que ya están realizando comprando más mercaderías en algunos casos o insumos para la elaboración de productos en el caso de las señoras que se dedican a la venta de comestibles.

Entre las actividades podemos citar: venta de comidas, frutas, verduras, despensa, venta de artículos para el hogar, carbón, peluquería así como también algunas son costureras y otras se dedican a la venta de ropas.

Cada una de ellas anhela poder dar una buena educación a sus hijos, así como también alimentación y un buen ambiente familiar. Ellas desempeñan sus roles de madres y esposas a la par que son micro empresA. luchadoras y exitosas. Ellas saben que hoy día el campo laboral está cada vez mas competitivo por ello luchan para que sus hijos puedan acceder el día de mañana a una educación universitaria.

Hoy solicitan todas un nuevo crédito que podrán invertir en sus negocios y así progresar día a día; entre las mercaderías a ser adquiridas citamos: frutas como naranjas , bananas ,piña, melón, sandías y manzanas; tomates, lechugas, cebollas, zanahorias, carbón, ingredientes para la elaboración de comidas como carne, leche, sal, harina, artículos para el hogar y para peluquería, entre otros.

loans.use: Purchase of fruits, vegetables, meats, flour, salt, oil, cleaning supplies, hairdressing supplies such as scissors, rollers, shampoo, lotions, clothing, charcoal, fabric, etc.

loans.name: Flor De Ventiila Group

texts.es:
"Flor de Ventilla" Association has been part of the Pro-Mujer (Pro-woman) family for over a year. The association was formed by a group of fifteen responsible working women within the center.

They were mainly engaged in the sale of second-hand American clothing, but due to legal conflicts with the city authorities they had to cease this activity and seek other types of activity. Currently, they are engaged in the buying and selling of consumer electronic equipment (radios, televisions, portable CD players, DVDs, etc.)

To buy these items, they need to travel outside the country, which requires a higher level of funding to purchase the goods and to pay for their traveling expenses. This is an investment, however, that in time will provide more profits and consequently their business will thrive.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La asociación “flor de ventilla” pertenece a la familia de Pro-Mujer hace mas de un año, grupo formado por 15 personas que trabajan con mucha responsabilidad dentro el centro. Ellas en gran parte se dedicaban a la venta de ropa americana (usada), pero por conflictos legales con la municipalidad esta actividad quedara vetada por algún tiempo motivo que les llevo a buscar otro tipo de actividad. Ahora intentan dedicarse al comercio de equipos electrónicos ( radios, televisores, discman, dvds y otros, para poder comprar estos artículos necesitan realizar viajes al exterior del país lo que implica solicitar mayores créditos para la compra de estos y pagar sus pasajes de viajes, una inversión que con el tiempo les traerá ganancias y con esto sus negocios prosperaran

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase consumer electronic products

loans.name: Flor De Urkupiña Group

texts.es:
“Flor de Urkupiña” Association is part of the Senkata Group, situated in the city of El Alto. The group is mainly engaged in the preparation and sale of exquisite spicy meat pies from wooden carts at different locations in the city. Unfortunately, many of these carts are worn-out and damaged due to constant use and climatic conditions. They need to be repaired or replaced, as appropriate.

To generate higher revenues and improve the living standard of their households, Flor de Urkupiña Association requires funds to buy new carts or to cover the rental costs of suitable sites for the sale of their products.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La asociación “Flor de Urkupiña pertenece al centro focal Senkata ubicada en la ciudad de el Alto. Gran parte del grupo se dedica a la preparación de exquisitas tucumanas y salteñas (empanadas fritas y al horno) que las venden en carritos instalados en distintos lugares de la ciudad. Lamentablemente muchos de estos carritos por las condiciones del clima y el uso ya se encuentran bastante deteriorados, lo que les obliga a remplazarlos o repararlos según el caso. La asociación flor de Urkupiña necesita dinero para poder comprar otros carritos o cubrir alquileres de ambientes adecuados para la venta de estos productos. Con el unico objetivo de generar mayores ingresos para mejorar la economía de sus hogares

loans.use: Capital to acquire tools for their business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pro Mujer Bolivia - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Semilla Group

texts.es:
Sale of garments is the main activity of this group of fifteen women who wish to improve their standard of living. Thanks to Pro-Mujer ("Pro-woman"), they are achieving their aim. Early morning every fortnight, they travel to Iquique (Chile) and Desaguadero (at the border with Peru) to buy clothes at wholesale prices. They are then offered for sale at major markets in La Paz.

They need capital to purchase or rent a more appropriate and permanent retail site from which to sell their goods. This would increase their income and would allow them to save for the future of their families.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

El comercio de ropa es la principal actividad de quince mujeres deseosas de mejorar su estilo de vida, que gracias a Pro-mujer lo están consiguiendo. Muy temprano cada quince días, realizan viajes a Iquique (chile), y al Desaguadero (frontera con Perú), de éstos lugares compran ropa al por mayor para luego comercializarla en los principales mercados de La Paz, Necesitan capital para poder comprar puestos fijos y/o alquilar ambientes más adecuados para ofrecer sus productos de esta manera generar mayores ingresos que les permita ahorrar para el futura de sus familias.

loans.use: Capital requirement for the acquisition of permanent retail site

loans.name: Santiago

texts.en:
Santiago Ofir V. Correa lives in Ciudad del Este with his wife Antolina and his two children.

Many years ago, Santiago started working in a bookstore called Cassol, where he gained experience in the field. Tired of being an employee, he decided to open his own bookstore in the shopping center of Ciudad del Este. Santiago sells articles used in writing such as paper, pens, quills, inkstands, pencils, and blank books. It is worth mentioning that the store is located in a strategic place, because Ciudad del Este is a commercial city. Usually Paraguayans go to Ciudad del Este only to buy things; from electronic devices to clothes.

Besides the bookstore, Santiago owns a grocery store. Santiago’s wife is the one responsible for the “Despensa” (grocery store). Antolina stays the entire day in the Despensa selling products such as milk, drinks, cigarettes, pasta, etc. The Despensas in Paraguay could be considered as mini supermarkets.

The money provided by this loan is intended to be used for the purchase of paper and other things for Santiago’s bookstore. There is a huge demand for paper and without this loan the increasing demand would not be satisfied.

loans.use: Purchase of paper, pens and books

loans.name: Bella Vista Group

texts.es:
Seventeen women constitute part of the Bella Vista Association, which belongs to the main Los Andes Group. The Los Andes Group has worked in partnership with Pro-Mujer for the last eight years and it has always complied with the terms of the loans granted to it.

Almost all the children confirm that the financial support of their families is basically the responsibility of their mothers since, unfortunately, most of the women were abandoned by their husbands, forcing them to become heads of their households.

Handicraft is the main activity of the group and original garments woven in Alpaca wool are in great demand by their customers. In addition, members of the association also produce quilts, blankets, scarves, etc. They need more capital to buy raw materials for making more products and to enable them to export these products.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

17 mujeres forman parte de la asociación Bella Vista que pertenece al centro focal Los Andes que trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer hace ocho años, demostrando siempre cumplimiento en cuanto a sus créditos. Casi todas hijos afirman que la economia de sus hogares depende basicamente de ellas ya que lamentablemente a la mayor parte de ellas sus esposos las abandonaron teniendo que ser jefes de familia. La artesanía es la actividad principal del grupo, originales prendas tejidas en lana de alpaca son la mayor atracción para sus compradores,, además también producen mantas, mantillas, chalinas y otros. Necesitan mayor capital para la compra de materia prima para, realizar mayores productos y poderlos distribuir al exterior.

loans.use: Require more capital for the purchase of raw materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pro Mujer Bolivia - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mujeres En Acción Group

texts.es:
The group “Women in Action” was formed one year ago and the majority of the original members still work in the group. The members of this group have a variety of productive businesses such as the sale of handicrafts, groceries, charcoal, newspapers, jewelry, linen goods and clothing among others.

The loan which they will get as a group is a great help for these women’s businesses. They will use it as operating capital to buy necessary merchandise for sale as they are always looking to expand the variety of the products they offer in order to increase their clientele.

In addition to being microentrepreneurs, these women support their families as mothers and wives. This is something that is common in their country because women play a very important role in the family as they are the moral and emotional support for the rest of the family. The greatest wish that these women have is the wellbeing of their children. They hope that their children will succeed by getting an education and getting better jobs so that they don’t have to suffer all day to support their families as these women do.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

El comité “Mujeres en Acción” tiene 1 año de formación mantiene a la mayoría de las primeras integrantes aun trabajando con el grupo, las señoras pertenecientes a este comité se dedican a diversas actividades productivas, como venta de manualidades, despensa, venta de carbón, kioscos, venta de bijouterie, venta de lencerías y ropas, entre otros.

El crédito que retiran de forma solidaria es una gran ayuda para el negocio de estas mujeres ya que ellas lo utilizan como capital operativo, comprando mercaderías necesarias para la venta pues buscan ampliar siempre la variedad de lo que ofrecen y además aumentar la cantidad de clientes.

Estas mujeres además de ser microempresarias, llevan adelante a sus familias como madres y esposas, esto es algo típico en nuestro país ya que las mujeres cumplen un rol muy importante en la familia, pues son el apoyo moral y sentimental para los demás integrantes de la familia. El deseo mas anhelado del corazón de estas mujeres es la de bienestar de sus hijos, ellas desean que ellos puedan salir adelante, estudiando y obteniendo mejores trabajos para no tener que sacrificarse de sol a sol para mantener a sus familias de la forma en que ellas lo hacen.

loans.use: Purchase of various merchandise for sale such as cosmetics, jewelry, drinks, fabric, wine, rice, sugar, oil, flour, charcoal, etc.

loans.name: Maria Serafina's Group

texts.es:
Maria, Ana and Maria have belonged to the Communal Bank Morenita II for one year.

Maria is 49 years old, is married and has four children She buys cereals, tuna, tara and cochineal at fairs and towns which she subsequently sells at markets in the city of Ayacucho. Sometimes she brings fruit from Lima and sells it at the Nery Garcia Market.

Ana is 39 years old, is a single mother and has two children. Ana sells wood in bulk which she acquires in Cangallo. Ana also breeds guinea pigs.

Maria is 25 years old, is married and has one child. Maria sells fruit in the Nery Garcia market. She acquires her fruit in the city of Pampas.

Maria, Ana and Maria need a loan of 600 soles, 300 soles, and 300 soles respectively. They will use the money to purchase cochineal, tara, wood and papaya.

Maria, Ana and Maria dream of having a larger business, their own home and that their children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

Maria, Ana y Maria pertenecen al Banco Comunal Morenita II hace 1 año.

Maria es casada, tiene 49 años y 4 hijos, Maria compra cereales, tuna, cochinilla, tara en las ferias y pueblos, productos que posteriormente vende en los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Algunas veces trae frutas de la ciudad de Lima y lo vende en el mercado Nery García.

Por otro lado Ana es madre soltera, tiene 39 años y 2 hijos, Ana vende leña al por mayor, su producto es adquirido en Cangallo. Además Ana se dedica a la crianza de cuyes.

Mientras que Maria es casada, tiene 25 años y 1 hijo, Maria vende frutas en el mercado Nery García, sus productos son adquiridos de la ciudad de Pampas.

Maria, Ana y Maria necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 300 soles, 300 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de cochinilla, tara, leña y papaya.

Los sueños de Maria, Ana y Maria son tener una negocio más grande, casa propia, sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase of cochineal, tara, wood and papaya.

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
The Amistad (Friendship) Association has been part of the family of Pro-Mujer (Pro-woman) for several years, complying with the terms of the previous 19 rounds of financing. The association is based in Alto Lima area, city of El Alto. Currently, it has 15 members and has proved to be a well-organized group on account of their loan repayment track record.

Most members of the association are married with children, almost all of whom are of school age. A few of the children have been unable to attend school due to their families’ lack of resources, the need to assist their parents in running their small businesses, and caring for their younger siblings. Association members are engaged in a variety of activities such as sale of meat, dairy products, and under-garments. Their main activity, however, is production of sportswear, which they sell at fairs in La Paz.

They believe they need additional capital to purchase better quality fabrics for the production of higher quality sportswear to attract more customers and increase their profits. Their sole aim is to improve their standard of living so that they can provide their children with better opportunities in life, particularly in the area of education.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La asociación denominada “la amistad” pertenece a la familia de pro-mujer hace ya varios años cumpliendo con 19 ciclos de crédito, esta se encuentra en la zona de alto lima, de la ciudad de el alto, a la fecha cuenta con 15 socias y ha demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito. Dentro el grupo la mayoría son casadas y con hijos, casi todos en edad escolar, existiendo algunos casos que por falta de recursos lastimosamente sus hijos no pudieron ingresar a la escuela. ya que estos deben ayudar a sus padres en sus pequeños negocios y cuidar de sus hermanos menores. Existen diferentes negocios dentro la asociación como ser; la venta de carne de pollo, de lácteos, ropa intima pero la actividad principal es la costura de prendas deportivas que una vez producidas las venden en las ferias de la ciudad de la paz ellas afirman que necesitan mayor capital para la compra de telas de mejor calidad de esta manera sus productos también tendrían mejor calidad y así obtendrían mayores clientes y por consiguiente mayores ganancias con el unico objetivo de mejorar su situación económica de esta manera ofrecer a sus hijos una mejor forma de vida principalmente en su educación.

loans.use: Additional capital for the purchase of better quality materials and fabrics

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Maruja has been a member of the “Morenita II” Communal Bank for two years. She is 32 years old and has a nine-year-old son.

Currently Maruja sells groceries and beverages from a rented locale, something she’s been doing for eight months. Besides that, she is also a beauty consultant and sells cosmetics from a catalog on credit to her friends and family.

Maruja needs a loan for $1,100 which she will use to stock her businesses with more products like garden and root vegetables, meat and clothing that she will bring from Lima.

She plans to use her savings to pay for her son’s education and to grow her business. Maruja dreams of owning her own home, economic stability, a bigger business and to provide a good education for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Maruja es socia del Banco Comunal Morenita II hace 2 años.

Maruja es conviviente, tiene 32 años y 1 hijo varón de 9 años, Maruja vende abarrotes y bebida en un local alquilado, actividad que inició hace 8 meses. Además Maruja es consultora de belleza, vende cosméticos por catalogo al crédito a amigos y familiares.

Maruja necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles, dinero que será invertido para surtir sus negocios con más productos como la compra verduras, tubérculos, carnes y ropa que traerá de la ciudad de Lima.

Sus ahorros lo utilizará en la educación de su hijo y para incrementar el capital de su negocio. Los sueños Maruja son tener casa propia, estabilidad económica, un negocio más grande y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase more products like vegetables, bulbs and meat in addition to clothing from Lima

loans.name: Guillermina's Group

texts.es:
Guillermina, Delia and Lucia have been members of the “Paz y Amor” Communal Bank for eight months, two years and four years respectively. They are from the community of Huayllapampa located 30 minutes from the city of Ayacucho, Peru.

Guillermina is 39 years old, separated and has four children, three of whom live with her. She works making handcrafted bricks.

On the other hand, Delia is 35 years old and has four children. She and her husband also work making handcrafted bricks. Besides that, Delia has a store where she sells food, beverages and candy.

Lucia is 42 years old and is married with four children. She buys tara (a plant used to make dye), sow bugs (an insect also used to make dye) and fruit from cactus plants and then sells them to distributors that come to her community.

Guillermina, Delia and Lucia need loans of 300, 900, 450 soles, respectively. The money will be used to buy tara, candies, cookies, crackers, rice, sugar and sow bugs.

The dreams of these three women are that their children become professionals, to have a store, to add a second story onto their house and to purchase an additional house.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Guillermina, Delia y Lucia pertenecen al Banco Comunal Paz y Amor hace 8 meses, 2 años, 4 años respectivamente. Ellas son de la comunidad de Huayllapampa que esta ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Guillermina es separada, tiene 39 años y 4 hijos de los cuales 3 viven con ella, Guillermina se dedica a la fabricación de ladrillos artesanales.

Por otro lado Delia es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 4 hijos, Delia junto a su esposo se dedican a la fabricación de ladrillos artesanales. Además Delia tiene una tienda donde vende comida, bebidas y golosinas.

Mientras que Lucia es casada, tiene 42 años y 4 hijos, Lucia compra tara, cochinilla, tuna y lo vende a intermediarios que van a su comunidad.

Guillermina, Delia y Lucia necesitan préstamos de 300 soles, 900 soles, 450 soles, respectivamente, dinero que será invertido en la compra de tara, gaseosas, galletas, arroz, azúcar y cochinilla.

Los sueños de Guillermina, Delia y Lucia son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener una tienda, construir el segundo piso de su casa y tener otra casa.

loans.use: Purchase tara, candies, cookies, crackers, rice, sugar and sow bugs

loans.name: Amanda's Group

texts.es:
Amanda, Paulina and Sonia have been members of the “Paz y Amor” Communal Bank for three years. They are from the Huayllapampa community located 30 minutes from the city of Ayacucho, Peru.

Amanda is 24 years old and has two children. She buys animals in her community and then later sells the meat.

On the other hand, Paulina is 38 years old and has five children. She sells beverages in her home and on Sundays she sells food and beverages in her community’s stadium.

Sonia is 22 years old and she and her husband work making handcrafted bricks.

Amanda, Paulina and Sonia need a loan of $450 that will be used to buy pigs and beer and to pay their workers.

The dreams of these three women are to improve their businesses, educate their children and to have an oven.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Amanda, Paulina y Sonia pertenecen al Banco Comunal Paz y Amor hace 3 años, Ellas son de la comunidad de Huayllapampa que esta ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Amanda es conviviente, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Amanda vende carne, los animales los compra en su comunidad y luego los beneficia.

Por otro lado Paulina es conviviente, tiene 38 años y 5 hijos, Paulina vende bebidas en su casa y los días domingos vende comida y bebidas en el estadio de su comunidad.

Por otro lado Sonia es conviviente y tiene 22 años, Sonia junto a su esposo se dedican a la fabricación de ladrillos artesanales.

Amanda, Paulina y Sonia necesitan préstamos de 300 soles, 600 soles, 300 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cerdo, cerveza y para el pago de peones.

Los sueños de Amanda, Paulina y Sonia son mejorar los negocios, sus hijos estudien y tener un horno.

loans.use: Purchase pigs and beverages; pay laborers

loans.name: Teresa Jesus' Group

texts.en:
Teresa and Marta have been associates of the community bank "Radiante" for a little over one year. In that time they have learned how to value themselves, save, and how to discuss subjects with their husbands and improve family relations. They like the community bank because people work with them to help them understand the procedures. They don’t feel belittled as in other banks.

Teresa is forty-seven years old. She is married and has nine children. Teresa travels in the area buying grains, potatoes and fruits depending on the season. Once a week she travels four hours to the coast to sell her products from the mountains. Teresa has been working in this area for many years.

Marta is forty-one. She is also married and has four children. Marta buys house-cleaning supplies in the city of Ayacucho. She then travels to small towns within two hours and sells them at local markets. Like Teresa, she has been working in this area for many years.

Teresa and Marta need loans of 1500 and 300 soles respectively. They will use their loans to buy more merchandise that they can then resell and realize a greater profit.

Teresa and Marta plan to use their savings at the community bank to buy a motorcycle taxi that their son can drive, and shoes and school supplies for their younger children. Their dreams are to own a store, continue to develop their businesses, and to own a nice home.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise for re-sale

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 46302

loans.name: Teodora's Group

texts.en:
Gladys, Filomena, and Teodora have been members of the community bank “Radiante” for one year. They like the program and look forward to continuing. Since joining the community bank they have learned how to value themselves, how to care for their children, and how to save.

Gladys is thirty-four years old. She lives with her partner and their four children. Gladys sells prepared food as well as a variety of grains at the local market in Ayacucho. Gladys has been working in this area for many years.

Filomena is forty-eight years old. She is married and has six children. Filomena has a stand where she sells vegetables in one of the local markets of Ayacuhco. She has been selling vegetables since she was a little girl.

Teodora is forty-three. She is married and has six children. Teodora travels to the countrysiD. to buy potatoes or other seasonal foods. She then sells them at the market. Teodora has been doing this for nine years. Recently Teodora has also started selling Herbal Life products such as vitamins.

Gladys, Filomena, and Teodora need loans of 600, 300, and 600 soles respectively. They will use these loans to buy more merchandise, and to pay for business travel costs.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Gladys, Filomena, and Teodora are saving to make home improvements, and to pay their children’s school fees. Their dreams are to own a well-stocked store, and a home.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise, and to pay for business travel costs

loans.name: Haydee's Group

texts.es:
Dionisia, Haydee and Maximina have belonged to the “Virtud” Communal Bank for four months, one year and eight months respectively.

Dionisia is 65 years old, separated and has five children. She sells vegetables in the Nery García market.

Haydee, on the other hand, is 27 years old and has four children. She sells ice cream that she buys from another business. She has a small pushcart that she uses to sell the ice cream in the streets.

Maximina is 36 years old and is the single mother of three children. She sells cheese at wholesale prices to different stores. Maximina buys the cheese in her town of Cochabamba in addition to making cheese with milk she buys from local producers. She also embroiders blankets.

Dionisia, Haydee and Maximina need a loan of $375. The money will be used to buy beets, onions, tomatoes, ice cream, milk and blankets.

The dreams of these three women are to have enough money for their businesses, to offer their children a good education and to buy cattle.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Dionisia, Haydee y Maximina pertenecen al Banco Comunal Virtud hace 4 meses, 1 año, 8 meses, respectivamente.

Dionisia es separada, tiene 65 años y 5 hijos, Dionisia vende verduras de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Nery García.

Por otro lado Haydee es conviviente, tiene 27 años y 4 hijos, Haydee vende helados que compra por mayor de una empresa, sus ventas lo realiza de manera ambulatoria en una carretilla.

Mientras que Maximina es madre soltera, tiene 36 años y 3 hijos, Maximina vende quesos al por mayor a diferentes tiendas, Maximina compra los quesos de su pueblo Ccochabamba y también elabora quesos con leche que adquiere de los productores. También Maximina borda mantas.

Dionisia, Haydee y Maximina necesitan préstamos de 400 soles, 200 soles, 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de betarraga, cebolla, tomate, helados, leche y mantas.

Los sueños de Dionisia, Haydee y Maximina son tener capital suficiente para sus negocios, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos y comprar ganado vacuno.

loans.use: Purchase beets, onions, tomatoes, ice cream, milk and blankets.

loans.name: Lucy's Group

texts.es:
Floriza, Lucy and Rosa have belonged to the “Nobleza” Communal Bank for one year, eight months and five years, respectively.

Floriza is 29 years old and has one child. She travels to the fairs where she buys animals and later sells the meat from a stand in the F. Vivanco Market. Besides that, Floriza grows potatoes on her land in Chiara and sells them in the markets of Ayacucho.

Lucy is a 30-year-old single mother with two children. She makes woven blankets and rugs that she sells in the market in Santa Clara. She also sells cheese in the same market.

Rosa is 51 years old, married and has five children. She makes ice cream with the help of her children and then sells both from home and in the fairs. In addition to that, Rosa buys cheeses and cereals in the fairs that she then sells to the stores in the city of Ayacucho.

Floriza, Lucy and Rosa need a loan of $825. With the money they will purchase sheep, goats, thread, dyes, barquillos (typical snack) and milk. The dreams of these three women are to have their own home, grow their businesses and to provide good nutrition and education for their children.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Floriza, Lucy y Rosa pertenecen al Banco Comunal Nobleza hace 1 año, 8 meses, 5 años, respectivamente.

Floriza es conviviente, tiene 29 años y 1 hijo, Floriza vende carne en un puesto del mercado F. Vivanco, Floriza viaja a las ferias donde compra los animales y posteriormente los beneficia. Además Floriza se dedica a la agricultura de papa en sus terrenos de Chiara, productos que vende en los mercados de Ayacucho.

Por otro lado Lucy es madre soltera, tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Lucy realiza trabajos de tejidos en telar como frazadas, pisos, que vende en el mercado Santa Clara. Además Lucy vende quesos de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Santa Clara.

Mientras que Rosa es casada, tiene 51 años y 5 hijos, Rosa elabora helados con ayuda de sus hijos, sus ventas lo realiza en su casa y también en las ferias. Además Rosa de las ferias compra quesos, cereales que vende a las tiendas de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Floriza, Lucy y Rosa necesitan préstamos de 800 soles, 600 soles, 800 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de ganado ovino, caprino, hilos, tintes, barquillos, leche y colorantes.

Los sueños de Floriza, Lucy y Rosa son tener una casa propia, surtir más su negocio, brindar una buena alimentación y educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase sheep, goats, thread, dyes, barquillos (typical snack) and milk

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.es:
Elizabeth, Roxana and Encarnación have been members of the “Nobleza” Communal Bank for two years.

Elizabeth, 38, is a single mother and has one child. She has three Internet stations in her home. Besides that, she also has a car that is used to transport people in Lima, a business managed by her father.

On the other hand, Roxana is 26 years old and has three children. She makes typical woven items like rugs and wall hangings that she sells in the F. Vivanco Market. Sometimes she also sells cheese.

Encarnación is 45 years old with five children. She sells meat to the stores and provides home delivery of animals purchased at the fairs.

Elizabeth, Roxana and Encarnación need a loan for $975 that will be used to purchase thread, dyes, sheep and to pay for auto repairs.

The dreams of these three women are to build their businesses and provide a good education for their children in addition to having more looms and their own homes.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Elizabeth, Roxana y Encarnación pertenecen al Banco Comunal Nobleza hace 2 años.

Elizabeth es madre soltera, tiene 38 años y 1 hijo, Elizabeth tiene cabinas de Internet en su casa. Además tiene un carro que realiza transporte urbano en la ciudad de Lima que esta administrado por su padre.

Por otro lado Roxana es conviviente, tiene 26 años y 3 hijos, Roxana elabora tejidos en telar como alfombras, tapices que vende en el Mercado F. Vivanco. Algunas veces Roxana vende quesos.

Mientras que Encarnación es conviviente, tiene 45 años y 5 hijos, Encarnación vende carne a las tiendas y reparte de casa en casa, los animales son adquiridos en las ferias.

Elizabeth, Roxana y Encarnación necesitan prestamos de 1600 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de hilos, tintes, ganado ovino y para los gastos de reparación de su carro.

Los sueños de Elizabeth, Roxana y Encarnación son implementar su negocios, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos, tener más telares y casa propia.

loans.use: Purchase thread, dyes, sheep and pay for auto repairs.

loans.name: Sitha Neoum Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sitha N. lives in Banh Chhkol Village in Kampong Chhnang Province.  She is the group leader of four members. She is 22 years old and the mother of one child.  She sells pots for a living. She is married to Mr. Chan Chheom, who is a security guard. Last year, she applied for a loan from AMK to buy a piece of land to resell for a profit. With the encouragement from her parents and husband, she would like to start another business. She is requesting a loan to buy rice, which she will keep in stock.  When the price of rice increases, she will sell it for a profit.

loans.use: to buy rice

loans.name: Reum

texts.en: Mrs. Reum P. is a 29 year old farmer who lives in Pouk District, Siem Reap Province. P. earns about $5 per day from khmer cake (Num Arkor) making . Her husband, Mr. Sao Som, is a 34-year-old farmer and part-time construction worker who also makes about $3 per day. They have four children, all of whom are young. With growing family expenses, they are looking for ways to increase their income. They seek a loan of $400 to purchase small pigs to raise and to purchase pig food. This loan will help them get more income and be able to support their family effectively.

loans.use: To purchase small pigs to raise and remain of loan is to purchase pig food

loans.name: Sokha Tong Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha T. is 33 years old and lives in Banh Chhkol village, which is a poor village located in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is the mother of five children, all of whom are studying in public school. She has a grocery store in the village that she manages very well. Her husband, Pov Lim, is a policeman. However, his salary is not enough to pay for the family's expenses. Last year, Mrs. Sokha T. obtained a loan from AMK to buy grocery items to sell in the village. Now, she would like to expand her business and increase her inventory with a new loan.

She is the group leader of four members. Mr. Sakhorn P. is not in the picture but his wife is.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items

loans.name: Kheourn Say Group

texts.en: There are four women in the loan group from Banh Chhkol Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Kheourn S., 53, has been selected to be the group leader.  She has seven children. Two of them work in a garment factory while another looks after the family cows. The four youngest children are enrolled in public schools. Her husband, Thuy Hang, is a subsistence farmer who cultivates his crop near the village. Mrs. Kheourn S. is a pot seller.  Previously, she serviced a loan from AMK and purchased a piece of land to re-sell for a profit. She now wants to buy more cows to breed.

loans.use: to buy more cows

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao K. and his wife live in Thnal Village, in the Siem Reap province. K. makes about $5 a day from making furniture. He and his wife live with their three children, who all attend school. Mao would like to apply for a loan of $800 to increase the volume of his furniture production, in order to support his children’s education and further expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood to make furniture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase hair and beauty products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her store

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Hoàng Thị Hận is 50 years old, she is a widow with 2 children. She joined TYM fund in 1997. She used the loans to invest in pig raising and fish farming. Her business has been going well for the last 10 years. Today, she concentrates her effort solely on raising pigs for breeding and for its meat. In her pig pen, there are always 5-10 pigs. Her 2 children are grown up and they help her a lot with things around the house. This time she is requesting a loan of 575 USD to buy feed for her pigs

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hoàng Thị Hận, 50 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1997. Chồng mất, gia đình chỉ có 3 mẹ con. Đồng vốn vay của Quỹ được chị Hận đầu tư cho chăn nuôi lợn và nuôi cá. Công việc luôn tiến triển tốt trong suốt 10 năm qua. Hiện nay chị Hận tập trung nuôi lợn sinh sản và lợn thịt. Trong chuồng nhà chị luôn có 5-10 con lợn. Hai con của chị hiện đều đã lớn và hỗ trợ chị rất nhiều trong việc gia đình. Vòng vốn này chị muốn vay 575USD để mua thức ăn chăn nuôi.

loans.use: Buy feed for pigs

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Phạm Thị L. is 51 and her husband 52. They have a 20 years old son. Before joining TYM, she used to sell basic goods at the local market. Since she did not have capital to keep a large inventory, she did not make enough money. In 2003, she started participating in TYM fund. She used the L. to invest in her business to have a large inventory. Sales were increasing. She has been able to buy a motorcycle to transport the merchandise. Today her income is 4-5 USD a day. She is seeking a L. of 450 USD to buy more merchandise for her store

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị L. năm nay 51 tuổi còn chồng chị 52. Anh chị có 1 con trai 20 tuổi. Trước khi vào Quỹ chị L. thường buôn bán hàng tạp hóa ở chợ nhưng do ít vốn nên hoạt động nhỏ lẻ, thu nhập thấp. Năm 2003, chị tham gia Quỹ, lượng vốn đầu tư cho cửa hàng tăng lên. Kinh tế phát triển, chị L. đã mua được xe máy nên việc đi lấy hàng rất thuận tiện. Hiện nay mức thu nhập của chị khoảng 4-5USD/ngày. Giá cả hàng hóa đang tăng, chị rất muốn vay thêm 450USD để mua thêm hàng về bán.

loans.use: Buy goods for grocery store

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is a 45 year old entrepreneur. She lives with her husband and four children, who are all in school. Emily is the proprietor of a cereal business which she started in 2006 and her husband works with the Kenya Airport Authority. She purchases grains, especially dry maize and beans, in bulk during harvesting season when the prices are low and then sells them to her customers when prices improve. She also supplies her goods to schools and colleges.

Emily requires $600.00 to further help her expand her business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand her business selling grains

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is the 35 year old married mother of five, who are all in school. She lives with her husband in the Sagam village of Siaya. She is a member of Schobac, a community based group. Jane is a full-time farmer who also sells fish to the local community. She buys fish (tilapia) in bulk from Yimbo--one of the beaches--and then sells to most of the hotels in Luanda. Despite stiff competition, increase in fish prices, and high transport cost, Jane has managed her business well. She requires $600.00 to invest in her fish business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Expand her fish business.

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Bùi Thị T. is 53 years old. She is a widow, raising 2 children by herself was very difficult. She joined TYM fund in 1999. She sells vegetables, beans and dried food. She is a hard working woman so she is able to make enough money to raise her family from just a small store. Her living condition is stable. She makes about 4-6 USD a day. Her oldest son has a job so he is able to help out financially. Her wish is to continue with TYM program so that she would be able to buy more merchandise for her store. She is seeking a loan of 950 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Bùi Thị T., 53 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1999. Chồng mất, gia đình chỉ có 2 mẹ con nên cuộc rất vất vả. Sau khi vay vốn chị T. đầu tư buôn bán các loại rau, đậu ... cùng một số hàng khô. Nhờ chịu khó nên cửa hàng nhỏ cũng đủ nuôi sống 2 mẹ con. Kinh tế gia đình dần dần ổn định. Mức T. nhập hiện nay của chị T. từ 4-6USD/ngày. Con trai chị cũng đã lớn và đi làm nên cũng hỗ trợ mẹ được rất nhiều. Mong muốn của chị T. là tiếp tục được vay vốn về mua hàng bán. Mức vốn đề nghị của chị vòng này là 950USD.

loans.use: Buy vegetables

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 33 year old married father of two living children. He lives with his wife in Sagam Siaya in Kenya. He started his cereals business in 2006 and specializes in selling dry maize to consumers. His hard work, perseverance, and good reputation, coupled with a well-established client-base ensure that his business will continue to grow despite stiff competition. He has applied for a loan of $700.00 to enable him purchase additional stock of cereals, such as beans, rice, and green grams, which are currently in high demand.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of cereals.

loans.name: Luong Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Lương Thị C., 54 years old, lives with her husband and their two children in Yên Đồng, ý Yên. She joins the TYM Fund in 1999. She uses her loans to invest in her dry goods store. Because of her industrious and friendly manner, she makes a good business. In average, she makes 4-6USD a day. In 2007, she takes her savings to buy a minivan. Her husband and two children then take turns to serve tourists in the area. The income is much heftier at 250-300USD a month. She would like to apply for a loan of 950USD to invest in the business, buying gas and maintain their van.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Lương Thị C., 54 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1999. Chị đang sống cùng chồng và 2 con tại xã Yên Đồng, huyện ý Yên. Đồng vốn vay qua các năm tham gia được chị C. đầu tư buôn bán hàng khô. Nhờ chịu khó, lại quen biết nhiều mối hàng nên thu nhập rất ổn định. Bình quân một ngày chị C. thu từ 4-6USD. Năm 2007, chị bàn với chồng mua ôtô chở khách tham quan du lịch.
