One daughter works, and the other three are studying at the university. Since birth she has lived in her mother’s house, which she inherited. The dwelling is constructed of “taquesal” (mud and wood) and it has a roof made of mud tiles. She wants to preserve the structure given she considers it historical, and with previous credits she has been able to make some small maintenance repairs. This eighth loan would help her to raise a new wall, to replace one that is crumbling, and also to make repairs to the roof. She is a person who is much-appreciated by her young students, as well as by the educational community for her responsible nature, her honesty and prestige among the teaching profession. She states she wants to continue working with AFODENIC for the attention they provide and for the loans which have been very opportune in her life.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La Profesora Nimia de 50 años de edad, tiene 18 años de trabajar en el area pre-escolar en los diferentes niveles en los Caracolitos Negros, es madre soltera de 4 hijos (3 mujeres y 1 varon), 1 hija trabaja, los otros 3 con estudios universitarios; desde su nacimiento ha habitado en la vivienda de su mamá, la cual heredo, esta vivienda esta construida de taquesal (barro y madera), techo de tejas de barro, ha querido conservar su estructura, ya que la considera una reliquia, con los creditos anteriores le ha dado un poco de mantenimiento pues han sido bastante bajos, este octavo credito lo incrementa un poco porque necesita levantar una pared que se esta cayendo y revisar el techo; es una persona que se ha sabido ganar el aprecio de sus alumnos que son muy pequeñitos, de la comunidad educativa y de la sociedad por su responsbilidad, honestidad y prestigio en el gremio magisterial, manifiesta continuar trabajando con AFODENIC por la atencion que recibe y sus creditos que han sido oportunos.

loans.use: Make improvements to her home.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Irma Cecilia

texts.es:
The young Irma Cesilia works for the ministry of education, a vocation she undertook at the age of seventeen while living in Piedra Pintada during the week and returning to her home for the weekends. She started to work with credit from AFODENIC in the year 2000, using her first loan to purchase land where she has built her home. With this ninth loan she wants to add “repello” (an extra coating of cement that is thrown onto the side of a wall) to her house before winter starts, to give it more strength and protection. She will also tile and, lastly, add paint, as she wants to give her five year old daughter and her mother a dignified and presentable dwelling. She has 10 years in the education sector and with much sacrifice she is working toward a degree in computers at the university. A year ago, she was transferred to the San Patricio School where she acts as director due to her responsibility, honesty and dedication to providing an education for the boys and girls of her community. She expressed gratefulness to AFODENIC because, thanks to this organization which is characterized for giving assistance to the most vulnerable, she has been able to reach goals that she’s had since childhood.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La Joven Irma Cesilia es trabajadora del MINEd, inició sus labores de educadora joven a la edad de 17 años en la Piedra Pintada, donde permanecia toda la semana, viajando a su casa los fines de semana. Inició a trabajar con credito en AFODENIC en el año 2000 utilizando su primer credito para comprar el terreno donde actualmente tiene construida su vivienda, con este noveno credito realizar el repello de su casa antes que inicie el invierno, para darle mas resitencia y proteccion, hara el embaldozado y finalmente le pintara, pues quiere dar a su hija de 5 años y a su mamá una vivienda digna y presentable de acuerdo a sus posibilidades, tiene 10 años de trabajar para el sector educativo y con sacrificio esta estudiando en la UNAN la Lic. en Informatica, hace 1 año fue trasladada a la Escuela San Patricio donde se desempeña como directora por su responsabilidad, honestidad y dedicacion al brindar el pan de la enseñanza a niños y niñas de su comunidad; manifestó estar agradecida con AFODENIC porque gracias a esta institucion que se caracteirza por dar atencion a los mas desprotegidos ha podido cumplir con la meta que se planteo desde muy joven.

loans.use: Improve her dwelling.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Much

texts.en: Much N. is 37 years old. She and her husband are originally from the province of Kampong Cham, and still make their family home there with relatives. However, as work is scarce in Kampong Cham, they have migrated temporarily north to work in the bustling border town of Poipet at the Thai-Cambodian border. Poipet is a wild town, characterized by casinos and heavy traffic. In the midst of all of this, Much N. runs a small tailoring business from which she earns US$4 per day. Her husband is a motor taxi driver and competes daily with the thousands of men who share his profession, for the patronage of arriving tourists. One of their children resides with them in Poipet and helps her mother with the tailoring business. Their other child is married and lives back in their home province of Kampong Cham. Much N. wants to invest in her own business by buying a sewing machine. Up to this point all of her work has been done by hand, but with a sewing machine she will be able to take on many more orders. She also wants to use her loan to buy her husband a new motorbike to help him stand out from the other motor taxi drivers.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and a motorbike.

loans.name: Sok Un Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sok U. lives in Kralanh Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is the group leader of a five member group. She is 33 and married with five children, one of whom is working in a garment factory while two others are enrolled in school. The last two stay at home because they are too young to work or study. Mrs. Sok U. is a basket maker and seller in the local village. Her husband, Heang Huon, is a construction worker and he also helps his wife. In order to improve her business, Mrs. Sok U. has asked for a loan to buy more raw materials to make baskets to sell.

loans.use: These women would like to buy raw materials to make baskets to sell.

payments.comment: This group has an End of Term loan. This means that principal is due at the end of the loan. AMK allows for pre-payments, thus some the members might pay some principal before the end of the loan. So Mrs. Sou Eng and Mrs. Khin Chuob decided to pay $10 each.

This Group Has An End Of Term Loan. This Means That Principal Is Due At The End Of The Loan. AMK Allows For Pre-payments, Thus Some The Members Might Pay Some Principal Before The End Of The Loan. So Mrs. Sou Eng And Mrs. Khin Chuob Decided To Pay $10 Each.

loans.name: Eoeun

texts.en: Eoeun S. is 41 years old and lives in Prey Veng province. Since 1999, she has had her own stand selling fruits and vegetables. She makes US$2.50 per day. Her husband, Son Choeun, is an army officer stationed in the neighboring province of Kandal. Even as an army officer, his daily income only amounts to US$5. They have five children together, only one of whom is old enough to work, and he is a teacher earning US$70 per month. She wants to expand her business so she can further provide for her four children still economically dependent and at home. Her loan would go towards increasing the size of her store and inventory. If she can have access to enough money she will be able to afford fruits and vegetables that normally only higher end sellers can afford, greatly raising her income.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Keav Mom Group

texts.en: The group in Kralanh Village in Kampong Chhnang Province consists of four members. Mrs. Keav M., 46, has been selected to be the group leader. She uses palm leaves to make mats that she sells. She is married to Mr. Yeng  Eng who is a construction foreman and they have five children, one of whom is a construction worker as well, while three others are students; the youngest is too young to work or study. Mrs. Keav M.’s business is going well and she now wants to expand it, but she does not have enough money. Thus, she has requested a loan to buy more palm leaves to increase her business as well as to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: These women would like to buy palm leaves to make mats.

loans.name: Leang

texts.en: Leang N. is 41 years old and unmarried. Being a single woman at this age is very uncommon in Khmer culture. But she still enjoys an active family life living with her younger sister’s family, including her four nephews. She sells vegetables from a small grocery store outside her home, earning approximately US$5 per day. With her loan she hopes to buy more grocery products to expand her vegetable selling business into a full grocery store.

loans.use: To buy grocery products.

loans.name: Kroch

texts.en: Kroch Y. is 34 years old and lives in Kampong Cham province. She is a professional middleman, brokering sales between rubber plantations and companies looking to purchase their products. She earns US$4 per day. Her husband, Cheo Yon, also deals in Khmer natural resources as a logger. He makes US$5.60 per day working for a commercial logging firm. Together they support six children. One of the kids is a construction worker, and the rest are all in school or still too young to attend. Kroch Y. would like to branch out of her current business to begin a small farming operation. Kampong Cham is known for its yams, a relatively profitable crop. She needs money to be able to afford her first plot of land and the yam seeds for her first crop.

loans.use: To rent farm land.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum P. is 32 years old and lives in Kampong Cham province. Since 1990 she has been a fish seller, meaning she has worked the markets in Kampong Cham since she was 14 years old. She has become quite good at her job managing a daily income of US$10. Pon Sokthy, her husband, is a motor taxi driver earning US$3.50 per day. Being a motor taxi driver in Cambodia is only a step above unemployment in most cases. It is inconsistent work and requires long hours under hot sun. Drivers who are fortunate manage to find work in larger cities and develop a regular client base. Pon Sokthy does relatively well in the capital city of Kampong Cham province. Together they provide for their three children. All of the kids are fully enrolled in school, another impressive achievement for your average poor Khmer family. Sum P. wants to help her husband develop a more consistent source of income by purchasing some farm land by their home on which they can grow rice and raise pigs. Their loan would go towards the start up costs for this venture.

loans.use: To buy farm land and pig feed.

loans.name: Nhim Yan Group

texts.en: Mrs. Nhim Y. is 53 and lives in Kralanh Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her group consists of four members and she is the group leader. She is a single mother with three children, two of whom are garment workers and the other is a student. She is a mat maker who uses palm leaves to create mats. At present, she does not have enough money to invest in her business, hence she decided to apply for a loan to buy more palm leaves in order to expand her business and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: These women would like to buy palm leaves to make mats to sell.

loans.name: Phin

texts.en: Phin C. is a 45 year old widow. She makes a good living in Phnom Penh selling scallops. She earns US$27 per day. However, this amount represents her total sales, not profit, and most of her money goes back into buying the scallops to sell. She has five children. Two of her children are already married. Two of her sons are professional dancers earning US$5 per day. She also has a daughter who goes to school on a scholarship that also pays US$3.50 per day so she can devote herself fully to her studies. Phin C. wants to take out a loan specifically to increase her profits from her scallop selling business. She will use the loan to purchase scallops cheaply and in bulk and thereby maximize her later profits. She also will use some of the money to invest in mechanic tools for one of her sons who wants to start working with motorbikes for a living.

loans.use: To buy scallops in bulk.

loans.name: Eourn Long Group

texts.en: Mrs. Eourn L. lives in Kralanh Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 42 and a basket and mat seller in the village. She is the group leader in a group of six members. She is married to Mr. Sareourn Kheav, who is a construction foreman, and they have two children, one of whom is working in garment factory while the other is attending the local school. To support her family needs, Mrs. Eourn L. is trying to find a good way to improve her business. Thus, she decided to apply for a loan to buy raw materials and start making her own baskets to sell. The man in the picture is Mrs. Eourn L.'s husband, since she wasn't available at the time that the picture was taken.

loans.use: These women would like to buy raw materials to start making baskets to sell.

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov S. is a widow in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She is only 41 years old and still has all three of her children living with her in the family home. Only her oldest daughter can work with her at her grocery store. The grocery store earns the family US$5 per day. A unique economic opportunity has presented itself in that rice prices in Cambodia are currently soaring. She wants to take advantage of this situation by purchasing a stock of rice to sell at her grocery store to increase her profits as the prices only seem to be going up with no sign of slowing down.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk.

loans.name: Chantha Mech Group

texts.en: Mrs. Chantha M. is the group leader of a group of four members in Kralanh Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 29 and a widow with two children whom are students. She is a basket and mat seller who can generate a small income to support the family. The household relies only on Mrs. Chantha Meh's work. She never obtained a loan from any MFI and now she has the chance to obtain one in order to improve her business and thus her family's conditions. With this loan, she would like to buy raw materials to make her baskets.

loans.use: These women would like to buy raw materials to make baskets to sell.

payments.comment: This group has an End of Term loan. This means that principal is due at the end of the loan. AMK allows for pre-payments, thus some the members might pay some principal before the end of the loan. So Mrs. Chantha Mech, Mrs. Lim Heng and Mrs. Thol Phan repaid $8 each; additionally,  Mrs. Thuon Phan decided to pay $9.

loans.name: El

texts.en: El S. is 44 years old. She farms rice in her home province of Kampong Cham. This is a hard profession and her profits only come out to US$1 per day of work. She has known work in the fields all her life, however, as she has been farming since 1979. Her husband, Sang Chea, is the local barber. He earns US$2 per day. Of their four children, only one is married. Two of the older unmarried children contribute to the family income. One is a garment factory worker, earning US$80 per month and the other works in construction, earning US$3 per day. She wants to support her husband in his unique trade by buying him better tools to use for cutting hair. Barbers in the provinces rarely have more than a comb, a flat razor, and a pair of rusty scissors. With more modern tools he will attract much more business than he does now.

loans.use: To buy barber tools.

loans.name: Popeal Khaer Iii Group

texts.en: Fifteen people in Popeal K. Village joined to form one Village Bank in Kandal Province. Mr. Tak T. is 31 and he is the Village Bank President. He is a subsistence farmer and the father of one child who is too young to work or study. His wife, Mrs. Chanthy Kong, is a farmer too. Mr. Tak T. and his wife usually sow twice a year. During the monsoon season, they plant rice and during the dry season, they grow vegetables. Most of their income comes from the portion of agriculture products which they sell for a profit. Previously, Mr. Tak T. had obtained a loan from Amret Co.,LTD for his rice field. Last year, their child got a bad cold and was sent to a health care center which was rather costly. Their child is now ill again and needs to be cured. For this reason Mr. Tak T. does not have enough money to buy seeds and fertilizers for his plantation. Thus, he asked for a loan to buy such supplies and be able to grow rice during the upcoming wet season.

loans.use: This group would like to buy seeds and fertilizers for their plantation.

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en: Mr. Chheang C. makes about $5 per day making palm sugar. His wife, Mrs. Phan Ngek, is a farmer and makes about $2 per day pigs breeding. They live with their two children in Beng Village, in the Siem Reap Province. All of their children are young. With growing family’s expenses, they need to expand their business. They seek a loan of $800 to purchase farm land to expand their farming business. This loan will improve their income to support their family sufficiently. (The Photo is C.’s wife)

loans.use: To purchase farm land to expand their farming business

loans.name: Sopheak Say Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheak S. is a tailor in Prey Khmer Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 27 and the group leader of a group of five members. She is a single mother with two children who are too young to work or study. Her household relies on her business. At present she does not have enough money to buy fabric to make clothes for her customers. She has never obtained a loan before; she now asked for a loan to buy fabric in order to be able to improve the service she can offer to her customers.

loans.use: These women would like to buy fabric to make clothes.

payments.comment: This group has an End of Term loan. This means that principal is due at the end of the loan. AMK allows for pre-payments, thus some the members might pay some principal before the end of the loan. So Mrs. Darann Mao decided to pay $15 in advance.

This Group Has An End Of Term Loan. This Means That Principal Is Due At The End Of The Loan. AMK Allows For Pre-payments, Thus Some The Members Might Pay Some Principal Before The End Of The Loan. So Mrs. Darann Mao Decided To Pay $15 In Advance.

loans.name: Beourn's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Beourn K. lives in Phray Bak Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is the group leader of a five member group. She is a housewife with five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while an other is a teacher. One is attending state school while the last one stays at home. Mrs. Beourn K. stays at home to cook food for her family. Her husband, Veasna Nith, is a province officer. Last year, the youngest child got a brain fever S. he was sent to a private hospital which cost $250 out of the family budget. Now everybody in the family is in good health and can work. To better support family expenses, though, Mrs. Beourn K. wants to start her own business: she requested a loan to buy rice to keep in stock to be sold later at a better price.

loans.use: This group would like to buy rice to keep in stock to be sold later at a better price.

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Khun K. is 42 years old, married, and has five children. Khun and his family live in Rumchek Village, in the Siem Reap Province. Two of his children attend school, and Khun needs to supply their educational costs. Khun earns an average of $4 day from selling pork, while his wife, Len, earns around $1.50 selling groceries at the market. Khun would like a loan of $1,100 to purchase meats and improvements for his grocery store to increase the family’s income to support his children and household.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to sell meats and decorate grocery store

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en: I am Sajida Parween from Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. I was married four and a half years ago and live in a joint family system. My husband and I both dropped out of school after completing our secondary education. B., my husband, operates an electronics store where he sells items such as fridges, televisions, and irons etc. He started this shop five years ago and sells items at his shop on installments to people of lower class who cannot afford to buy on upfront payment. Our business generates decent profits for us but we need to further improve our income and therefore we are requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 950.

loans.use: Expand our electronic goods store

loans.name: Razia

texts.en: My name is Razia A. D. from Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. I am married with six kids: three boys and three girls. My eldest daughter is in grade eight and the next two daughters are in grade five, whereas two boys are not of school-going age yet and the eldest is in grade three. My husband raises cows and sells their milk to neighboring houses I also help him in this business. We sell 40 to 50 kg of milk daily. Our business has grown substantially over a number of years by acquiring loans from Asasah, a microfinance institution in Pakistan. This year again we need another loan to buy an additional cow for our milk business.

loans.use: Need to buy an additional dairy cow

loans.name: Suhailee

texts.ru:
Suhailee is married and has 3 children. He sells candy on the market. Currently he sells truffles, caramel candy, cookies and chocolate. He has been working in this business for the past 5 years. A good sales location is about to become available right next to where he sells his goods. He needs money to reserve this spot and start selling goods there as well. His wife and daughters will be working there selling candy. For this purpose he has come to MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Сухайли женат имеет троих детей. Он торгует на рынке конфетами: трюфелями, карамелями, печеньями и шоколадами. Он сидит на рынке 5 лет. Не далеко от его точки освобождается место, поэтому ему необходимо забронировать и там торговать. Там будет сидеть его дочери и супруга, они также будут торговать сладостями. Для этого ему необходимо определенная сумма, и он обратился в Микроинвест. Он будет арендовать еще одну точку, так как его обеспечивают товаром одна компания это помещение ему необходима.

loans.use: Increase variety of goods for sale

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 46575

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen I. resides in a big city of Pakistan, Lahore. She is married with two kids: one girl and one boy. She and her husband both are uneducated but they do not want the same fate to befall their kids. Therefore, they work very hard to improve and increase their income slowly but steadily.

Nasreen’s husband sells vegetables in a nearby food market. He has been in this business for the past four years. They need a loan to increase their income by investing in their vegetable business; this increase in income will help them achieve a better living status.

loans.use: Expand our vegetable business

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: I have been married for four years and have two kids: one boy and one girl. Both of my kids are not of school-going age yet. I reside with my family in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. My husband runs a grocery store; he started the store three years ago. He sells all daily-use items in his shop. He works at the shop from 6 am to 10 pm daily.  We live in a joint family system and therefore we want to save extra profits from our income to build a house of our own.

loans.use: Improve the range of items in our grocery store

loans.name: Rehana

texts.en:
Rehana A. was married eight years ago and resides in Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. She says, "I have three kids: two boys and one girl. My eldest kid is nine years old, the next is three years old and our daughter is one and half years old. Currently, only my eldest son attends school, whereas the others are not of school-going age yet."

A few years ago Rehana's husband used to do tailoring, but now her husband runs a shop selling gas cylinders and provides re-filling services for the cylinders as well. They also own a rickshaw, which they have rented out to supplement their income.

They would like a loan to start up a mobile phone repair business in partnership with her brother. Rehana's husband remarks that, “Now our times have changed and we have a television for our house.”

loans.use: Start a mobile phone repair store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma N. has been married for the last three and half years. She has two sons, the elder of whom is two years old and the other is a year old. This family lives in Lahore, Pakistan.

Salma and her husband both were educated up to grade twelve and then dropped out of school due to various financial problems in their families. They hope and work very hard to ensure that their kids will be able to finish their schooling.

Salma’s husband and his brother-in-law together operate an electronics shop where they sell items on an upfront cash basis as well as on installments. They have been in this business for the last four years. They need a loan to buy a few items for their shop.

loans.use: Expand electronic goods shop

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz I. lives in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. She was married 32 years ago and has four kids: three boys and one girl, all of whom are married. Shahnaz’s husband is a welder and has run a workshop in one of the busy markets for many years. He has also employed a few workers to help him in the business.

Shahnaz's husband gets orders from various factories and manufactures the required items. His business generates decent profits for them and helped them to marry their kids in a dignified manner. Now, they wish to be able to fill bigger orders for which they require a loan.

loans.use: to fill bigger orders for their welding business

loans.name: Moshi

texts.en:
Moshi is 37 years old and is a married woman with 4 children. Moshi has been a clothes seller since 2007. Everyday, she works from 9am to 8:30pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Subira's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Subira is 39 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 20 and 19. She and her husband also takes care of 2 other children. Subira owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 12pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more grocery items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Debora and Benadetha.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her business.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Mom S. makes around $1.33 per day breeding pigs. Her husband is a staff member of Hallo Trust which is an international organization and makes $6.66 a day. S. lives with their five children in Trapeang Trom Village, Siem Reap Province.  S. seeks a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike, which will dramatically reduce the family's traveling expenses.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to use in family

loans.name: Lilian's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Lilian is 31 years old and is a divorced woman with 4 children, ages 11,9,7 and 4. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, age 24. Lilian has been asoft drink seller since 2008. Everyday, she works from 1am to 2pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more soft drinks items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Silivian, who has grocery business dealing.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks items for her business.

loans.name: Sean

texts.en: Sean N. is 32 years old. She and her husband, Thong Vannak, are vegetable sellers in their home province of Kampong Cham. Their combined profits come out to only about US$3 per day. Their two children are both students. Their family hopes to be able to send them all the way through school instead of pulling them out eventually to work, as most poor families must. With their microloan, they want to invest in a large stock of vegetables which they can sell in bulk to market sellers in other districts.

loans.use: To buy vegetables.

loans.name: Aisha's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Aisha is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18,15 and 11. She and her husband also take care of 1 other child, age 18. Aisha has been a clothes seller since 1992. Everyday, she works from 8am to 1pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Kellen and Hawa, who have businesses dealing in food sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Hasira's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Hasira is 51 years old and is a married woman with 7 children, ages 16-33 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other children, ages 12 and 13 years old. Hasira owns a small grocery, which she opened in 2004. Everyday, she works from 10am to 20pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more grocery items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Asha and Grace, who have businesses in food sales.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her business.

loans.name: Popeal Khaer Ii Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sareth T. is the Village Bank President in Popeal Khaer II in Kandal Province. She is 44 and the mother of seven children, one of whom is working in a greenhouse plantation field while an other is a motorbike taxi-driver. The remaining five are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Seourn Sao, is a motorbike taxi driver who generates only a small income to support the family. Mrs. Sareth T. is a farmer and last year she obtained a loan from Acleda Bank to grow vegetables. Unfortunately last year in August, her husband got a liver disease and curing him was very costly. These unforeseen expenses prevented Mrs. Sareth T. from being able to buy fertilizers and insecticides for her field. In order to be able to produce more healthy vegetables, she asked for a loan to buy fertilizer and insecticides. She will also use the loan to buy more vegetables seeds.

loans.use: These women would like to buy fertilizers, insecticides and vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Mwazani's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Mwazani is 34 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 9, 6, 5 and 2 years old. Mwazani has been a fish seller, since 2007. Everyday, she works from 10am to 9pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Dionisia and Subira, who have businesses dealing in clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en: Chhin S. is 42 years of age. Since 1999, she has worked hard farming vegetables in her home province of Kampong Cham. Her farm only earns her US$3 per day of profit. En Neum, her husband, is the primary breadwinner, earning US$6 per day selling rubber to local factories. They support their only child, who is a student, as well as themselves through these lines of work. With access to enough money, Chhin S. wants to buy a large stock of rubber for her husband to sell in bulk to nearby factories. This will give their family a much needed financial boost.

loans.use: To buy rubber.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sauda's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Sauda is 31 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 12, 8 and 4 years old. Sauda owns a small grocery, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 9am to 6pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more grocery items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Tatu and Godliver, who have salon and grocery businesses.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her business.

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en: Sreng M. is 35 years old and lives in Kampong Cham province. Kampong Cham is known for its river fishing industry, in which Sreng M. has her business. She runs a stand selling freshly caught fish each morning at the local market. She buys directly from the boats as they come in each day. Provincial markets have no access to any kind of refrigeration so perishable food must be sold on the day. She earns US$3 per day. Her husband is a mechanic specializing in cars. He does quite well, earning US$10 per day. They have three children. The oldest helps his father work on cars while the younger two are in school. Their loan will be put towards expanding her husband’s workshop. They will invest in new tools and commonly required spare parts.

loans.use: To expand their car mechanic business.

loans.name: Prisca's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Prisca is 24 years old and is a married woman. Sheowns a small shop of mobile phone items which she started in 2006. She works everyday from 9am to 5pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more mobile phone items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Prisca P., who has business dealing in clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more phone items for her business.

loans.name: Tes

texts.en: Tes N. is a 45 year old housewife who lives in Kampong Cham province. Her husband cares for their family by working as a police officer in Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh police officers are better paid than in other parts of the country, and he earns US$5 per day. They have five children together, two of whom are unemployed while the rest are students. Since her husband must commute every day from his home province of Kampong Cham to Phnom Penh, three hours away, his family wants to invest in a motorbike to help him save time commuting to work. Right now he is forced to hitchhike each day to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Amina's Zahanati Group

texts.en:
Amina is 40 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 13 and 17. Amina owns a small stock of poultry, a business she started in 2002. Every day, she works from 6am to 9pm at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food for her poultry. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Victoria, who has a business in food sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her poultry

loans.name: Sauda Nakumiza`s Group

texts.en:
Sauda is the leader of a group of five members. She is 30 years old and married with four children aged 11, 8, 6, and 3 years, all of whom are in school. The community she lives in is semi-urban. Sauda makes samosas, pancakes and chapattis, which she supplies to the nearby shops. Proceeds are collected in the evenings to purchase ingredients for the following day’s work, and there is a ready market for her goods. One of the challenges Sauda faces is the rising price of wheat flour, cooking oil and other ingredients she uses to make her products.

Her business has enabled her to pay school fees, increase stock, and contribute to the running of the home. The family has moved out of the low-lying area where they were renting to their newly-built house in a better environment. Sauda has paid back more than five loans, and with this latest one she plans to increase her stock and buy saucepans, plates, chairs, a charcoal stove and other implements for the new eating-place she intends to open.

loans.use: She plans to increase her stock and buy saucepans, plates, chairs, a charcoal stove and other implements for the new eating-place she intends to open.

loans.name: Nuru's Zahanati 1 Group

texts.en:
Nuru is 29 years old and is a single woman with 2 children, ages 12 and 9. Nuru sells clothes. She started her business in 2005. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Raya, who has a business in food sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: You

texts.en: Mrs. You V. is a palm sugar maker and makes about $3 per day. Her husband, Mr. Nut Ty, is a farmer and makes about $2 per day. They live with their four children in Bang Kong Khmom Village, Pursat Province. They request a loan of $500 to purchase equipments for palm sugar making in order to purchase palm sugar so they can then stock and sell . This loan will expand their business and improve their income to support their family sufficiently.

loans.use: To purchase equipments for palm sugar making in order to purchase palm sugar for stocking and selling.

loans.name: Kamwokya Ii Development Group

texts.en:
Faith M., the chairperson of the Kamwokya II Development group, is a multi-business woman. She rears 250 local and broiler chickens at her home, a business she has had for seven years. She also sells tap water. And through the chicken business, she was able to start up the food processing business where she makes and sells juice, cakes, and other confectioneries. In all these businesses, she employs no one but works hand-in-hand with some of her children. She needs a loan to help buy more chicks and stock chicken feeds because the prices are going up by the day.

Faith is 53 years and married with six children. Though only one of her children is still in school, she cares for five other kids of which four are in school. The rest of the children are grown up and working in their own businesses.

Her group has been together since 1992 and they are grateful to Pearl Microfinance for the loans that have enabled them with the smooth running of their businesses.

loans.use: Faith would buy more broiler chicks and stock chicken feeds with her part of this group loan

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pearl Microfinance Limited - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Rupa

texts.en:
Mrs Rupa G. is a 32 year old lady who lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family with her husband and two sons. Her husband's name is Murali G. and he works in a noodle factory. Her older son is studying in grade 2 and younger son is in pre-primary school.

Mrs G. is a farmer in Sainbu-Bhaishapati. She grows different types of vegetables in her farm. Due to the lack of technology, most of the farmers in this area depend on seasonal farming. Mrs G. sells her vegetables in the local vegetable market in the morning and the evening.

Now she is requesting a loan of Rs 10000.00 to buy seeds and fertilizers for her work. She needs the income to provide better education for her children and she wishes to help her husband to upgrade the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers for her farm.

loans.name: Elizabeth's Zahanati 1 Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 30 years old and is a single woman with 2 children, ages 5 and 2 years old. Elizabeth is a food seller. She started her business in 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Anna, who has a business in clothing sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Ambica

texts.en:
Ambica G. lives in a joint family with her father-in-law, mother-in-law and husband in Sainbu-Bhaishapati. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Her husband's name is Ram G. and he is a salesman in a noodle factory and her father-in-law is a retired officer.

Mrs G. is a farmer in Sainbu-Bhaishapati. Due to the lack of new technology she has to depend on seasonal farming. She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and the evening.

Now she is requesting her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farm. She wishes to upgrade the living standard of her family with the income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Kavule Effort Lending Group

texts.en: For 15 years, Juliet N. has had a drug shop in Kavule, Mukono district. She is married with four children and also cares for two orphans, all of whom are in school. She is one of the founding members and the chairperson of the Kavule Effort Lending group. She has never regretted the decision she took to join. When asked about her plan for the loan, she says she is going to buy more medicine for her drug shop and use a quarter of it to pay school fees for all her children. Her clients are come-and-go patients. She is so grateful for the loans but above all for her husband for allowing her to be a part of her group for such a long time.

loans.use: Juliet would buy more medicine for her drug shop and pay her children's school fees with her part of this group loan.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en:
Ven S., age 55, is a true entrepreneur and lives with her husband Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. They have four children, three of whom are students and live away from home, while one is employed as a construction worker in the province with a salary of $50 a month. Mrs. Ven S. is a farmer, and she makes on average less than one dollar per day. Her husband, Pen Ros, works as a construction worker building houses, and earns around $1.60 of profit per day.

She faces problems with the water supply, and as a result her crop is not productive. Sometimes her output cannot support the family for the whole year and she has to purchase rice from the miller to feed the family. Because of the difficulties, she would like to receive a loan from Kiva to create another business selling groceries. This will provide her with an extra income to support the family.

loans.use: To purchase groceries.

loans.name: Kimhiv

texts.en: Mrs. Kimhiv N. lives in Popeal Khaer, a poor village in Kandal province. She is 58 and the mother of five children, one of whom is a construction worker, three are students and the youngest is at home. Mrs. Kimhiv N.’s family is very poor since both she and her husband, Vith Lim, are farmers. Last year, Mrs. Kimhiv N. obtained a loan from Acleda Bank to grow rice. This year her plantation has faced drought and insects attacks which resulted in a poor crop. Thus, she now requested a loan to buy insecticides and hire a pump to water her field. (Her husband is on the right in the photo).

loans.use: Mrs. Nuon would like to buy insecticides and hire a pump to water the field.

loans.name: Mwajuma's Jiliwaze Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is a married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 8 years old. Mwajuma owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $48 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Lazia, Tabia, Sophia, and Zaituni, who have businesses dealing in vegetables sales, banana sales, and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng S. is 49 years old and lives in Kampong Cham province where one child is employed as a garment worker; another child is a logger; and yet another is married and lives on their own. Mrs. Pheng S. owns a plot of farm land, where she grows rice, normally making less than one dollar per day. Her husband is a construction worker, who builds houses and sometimes has to go outside of the village to do the construction. He makes three dollars of profit per day.

Pheng S. would like to borrow some money from Kiva to purchase fertilizers to make her harvest more productive each year.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Thy

texts.en: Mrs. Thy S. lives in Ping Pong Village in Kandal Province. She is 46 and is a fruit seller in the local market. She is a widow with a child who works in a garment factory. Lately she has had problems selling her fruit which lasted too many days and got spoiled so that it could not be sold any longer. Last year, she obtained a loan from Acleda Bank to buy pigs to breed. Now she also asks for a loan from AMK to buy soil to fill in the house yard to prevent floods during the rainy season.

loans.use: Mrs. Suon would like to buy soil to fill in the house yard.

loans.name: Celina's Busara Group

texts.en:
Celina is 39 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 16 and 10 years old. Celina sells charcoal and vegetables. She started in 2000. Every day, she works from 12am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and vegetables. She will share this loan with her subgroup members MwaJ., Asha, Rahma, and Shani, who have businesses in charcoal sales, clothing sales, tailoring, a butchershop, and chicken sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Ishori

texts.en:
Mrs Ishori M. lives in Dhalko, which is located in the Kathmandu district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small businesses like grocery stores, small hotels and stationery stores.

Mrs M. lives in a single family with her husband, Mr Bal Krishna M., and two daughters. Her daughters are studying in grade 12 and 11 respectively.

Mr and Mrs M. opened a small hotel three years ago. They sell different types of food items in their hotel, especially Newari food. The demand for Newari food is increasing in that area so Mrs M. is requesting her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to buy necessary food materials.

loans.use: To buy food material for her small hotel.

loans.name: Kob

texts.en: Mr. Kob Y. is 29 and a subsistence farmer and a pig breeder in Angk Village in Kandal Province. He is married with a child who is too young to work or study. His wife Sokna Neang is a silk weaver in the local village. Mr. Kob Y. usually hires a person to work on the rice field and just waits for the revenue. Previously, he had obtained a loan from Brasac Co.,LTD to hire a person to cultivate the rice field. Last year Mr. Kob Y. had a big problem because many insects damage his rice and thus did not make enough money to pay his worker, therefore he asked for a loan to pay the wages.

loans.use: Kob would like to pay for his employee for his rice field.

loans.name: Twitike

texts.en: Twitike K. is from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania.  She is 23 years old, married, and has two children aged two and six.  In 2006, Twitike established a crops business with the help of SELFINA, an organization that works towards the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through sale and leaseback agreements for small farmers. She now requires a new loan of $175 in order to buy more crops.

loans.use: To buy more crops for selling

loans.name: Silvia's Riziki Group

texts.en:
Silvia, age 36, is the single parent of three children, ages 17, 14, and 2. She runs a poultry business, which she started eight years ago, as well as a charcoal business, which she began three years ago. She works at these businesses from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $180 from her work.

In the past, Silvia took two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to revive her chicken business when it was struggling to make a profit. She now hopes for a new loan to buy more chicks and feed for the chickens. She will share this loan with her loan group Riziki, which totals 19 members who guarantee each other in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Silvia is in the second row, third from the left.

loans.use: To buy more chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Mukasa Jane, Kavule Effort Group

texts.en: Jane M., the leader of this group, is a married woman with six children and another four relatives that she helps care for with her husband. She has a retail shop in Mukono just next to Stanbic Bank. She has been running the shop with her husband for ten years. Unlike other ordinary retail shops--that sell sugar, salt and edibles--her shop is for clothes, shoes, gomesi (ladies traditional wear), bags and jewelry. To get all these items on their shelves, they go to China and Japan for them in turns. Her dream is to import a container of their shop items and they are working towards that. They thank Kiva for the loans.

loans.use: Jane will import more clothes, shoes, bags and jewelry with her part of this group loan.

loans.name: Gradys

texts.en: Gradys M. is from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania.  She is 23 years, married, and has three children aged three, six, and 12.  In 2006, Gradys established her grocery business and bar, where many locals shop and enjoy themselves. She has already received and successfully repaid a loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan of $825 in order to increase her supply of goods.

loans.use: To buy more stock of beer and soft drinks.

loans.name: Ratna

texts.en:
Ratna N. is a resident of Dhalko. Dhalko is locted in the Kathmandu district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small businesses.

Mrs N. lives in a single family with her husband and two daughters. Her husband's name is Asha Bahadur N. and he works in a private office.

Mrs N. is a grocery shop keeper in Dhalko. She opened her grocery shop five years ago to upgrade the living standard of her family. She sells different types of grocery items in her shop like rice, maize, paddy, noodles and so on. Her daughters both help her in her shop.

Now Mrs N. is requesting her first loan of Rs. 10000.00 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her grocery business.

loans.name: Happyness

texts.en: Happyness M. is from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania.  She is 38 years old, married, and has five children between the ages of three and 18.  She also cares for seven dependents, who live with her because they are disabled.  In 2003, Happyness established her timber selling business with the help of SELFINA, an organization that works towards the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through sale and leaseback agreements. Happyness now requires a new loan of $425 in order to buy more timber stocks.

loans.use: To buy more stock of timber in bulk.

loans.name: Ratna Shova

texts.en:
Mrs Ratna Shova T., a 36 year-old lady, lives in Dhalko, Kathmandu. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small businesses. Mrs T. lives in a joint family with her mother-in-law, husband and four daughters. Her husband's name is Mr Raju T. and he works in a private office. Her four daughters are studying in grades 12, 10, 6 and 5 respectively.

Mrs T. is a grocery shopkeeper in Dhalko. She opened her grocery store three years ago to improve the living standard of her family, because the income of her husband is not sufficient to run her family smoothly. Mrs T. sells different types of grocery items in her shop such as maize, rice, noodles and so on.

Now she is requesting her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her grocery shop.

loans.name: Kayondo Ronald, Kavule Effort Group

texts.en: Ronald K. is a resident of Mukono and has a motorcycle and bicycle spare parts shop. He has been running the shop together with his wife for four years and a member of Kavule Effort for one year. He has four children and cares for an orphan. He has planned to buy more spare parts, which he gets from Jinja and Kampala. For increased savings, he has also started repairing motorcycles and bicycles in front of his shop, which has helped contain his customers in one place.

loans.use: Ronald would buy more spare motorcycle and bicycle parts with his part of this group loan.

loans.name: Sarita

texts.en:
Mrs Sarita L. lives in a joint family with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, husband and two daughters in Dhalko, Kathmandu. Her husband's name is Sunil L.. He has his own electronic shop. Her daughters are studying in grade 12 and 8 respectively.

Mrs Sarita opened her grocery store five years ago to upgrade the living standard of her family. She sells different types of grocery items in her shop and all her family members help her.

Now she is requesting her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to fulfill the increasing demand for grocery items of her customers.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her shop.
